Tammo Freese wrote:

>  > When I practise TDD, I often
>  > design interfaces, and forcing me to generate a method stub for a method
>  > I might not even like yet is annoying. Keeping the methods as strings
>  > allows me to write the test, compile it, and even run it before I decide
>  > whether the interface or method signature is good enough to start
>  > putting into stone.
> 
> 1) With that method, you never see the method
>     as a real method call as in EasyMock. Compare
> 
> control.expectAndReturn(mock.copy(destination, source), true);   // 
> EasyMock 1.2
> 
> expect(mock.copy(destination, source)).andReturn(true); // EasyMock 2.0 
> / 2.1
> 
> to
> 
> mock.expects(once()).method("copy").with( eq(destination), eq(source) 
> ).will(returnValue
> (true)); // JMock
> 
> In the EasyMock examples, both show how the method
> is used copy(destination, source) and returning true.
> It is easy to see that the parameters should be reordered,
> and with refactoring-tools, it's quite fast.
> 
> In the JMock example, it is not that easy to spot the method call, because
> the method name is in a string, and the parameters are separated from 
> this string.
> It is harder to see that the parameters should be reordered,
> and as refactoring tools don't work, it's a pain - especially if
> the method is used more than once already in the tests, you have to change
> every single ocurrence by hand.

As I stated before, while I acknowledge this problem, the other benefits 
from jMock make up for this cost /so far/, /for me/. I find that I don't 
change methods on interfaces too frequently. Typically, I change them on 
classes before I extract the corresponding interface. By the time I 
extract the interface, the method is quite stable.

Also, I introduce Parameter Objects quite quickly, which reduces the 
need to reorder parameters or change parameter lists.

> 2) Can you explain on how you test-drive a plain old java method then,
> without adding a body for it?

I might not have been clear: in this case, I'm test-driving class A, 
which I see needs a collaborator, so I introduce interface B. In this 
case, while test-driving an implementation for A, I'm designing the 
interface for B. It is B's methods (and not A's) which I can design 
without having even to declare a method signature. After I write a test 
and am happy with the design, I run the test, watch it fail because the 
new method is not yet on B, then I add it to B.
